title: Line 1155 writetouch to non-existent file
body:
Hello,

I am trying to run the PILEUP -> VCF_EXTRACT -> SPLIT workflow through gotcloud vc --conf my.config. On line 1155 from this commit (https://github.com/statgen/gotcloud/commit/f03fca07453a332a3c3ccd3061d9f4ef8edf7022#diff-e67da9ac72c8206f6cf7f682a0022e05) the code is: 

writeTouch("$vcf");

but $vcf does not exist. There is a $vcf.gz file that exists in that directory. When I manually gunzip the .vcf.gz file in that directory and re-run make it successfully runs through the workflow and creates the expected output. 

If I look at the old umake.pl code that is distributed as standalone code this is simply a touch not a writeTouch command. With the old umake.pl I had no issues running this workflow.

Best,
Karyn Meltz Steinberg

title: `$val` is not initialized in one branch
body:
I'm getting the error

```
Use of uninitialized value $val in concatenation (.) or string at /tmp/ptr-seqshop/gotcloud/bin/align.pl line 998.
```

At https://github.com/statgen/gotcloud/tree/master/bin/align.pl#L992, should there be `$val = ''`?

title: A GC-content graph is bounded (0,120)
body: At https://github.com/statgen/gotcloud/blob/fe80263131766c65862cc3692bc9c5c174f98fe3/src/qplot/src/BamQC.cpp#L1065 and https://github.com/statgen/gotcloud/blob/fe80263131766c65862cc3692bc9c5c174f98fe3/src/qplot/src/BamQC.cpp#L1072, the graph of GC-content has x-axis limits of `(0,120)` .  Should it be `(0,100)`?

title: Print errors/warnings to STDERR/STDOUT
body: Please print out any warnings/errors to STDOUT/STDERR in addition to any `.err` files.

title: Align test fails using gotcloud.1.17.5
body:
I am configuring a Docker image to run GotCloud. Below are the steps taken while testing on a base image with all the requirements. 

```
$ wget https://github.com/statgen/gotcloud/archive/gotcloud.1.17.5.tar.gz
$ tar -xzf gotcloud.1.17.5.tar.gz -C /usr/local
$ cd /usr/local/gotcloud-gotcloud.1.17.5/src
$ make
$ cd /usr/local/gotcloud-gotcloud.1.17.5
$ scripts/check_requirements.sh
WARNING:  '/usr/local/gotcloud/bin' does not exist.  Continuing...
Good, you appear to have 'java' installed
Good, you appear to have 'make' installed
Good, you appear to have 'libssl' installed at the correct level
#============================================================
#   '/usr/local/gotcloud/test/umake' does not exist so you cannot test this install
#   Install it by doing 'sudo dpkg -i gotcloud-test_*.deb'
#============================================================
```

So it is not recognizing that gotcloud exists due to the specific version name, I realize that if I did a `git clone` this issue would not arise, or I could move `gotcloud-gotcloud.1.17.5` to `gotcloud`. Proceeding...

```
$ ./gotcloud align --test /root/testalign
Removing any previous results from: /root/testalign/aligntest
Running GOTCLOUD TEST, test log in: /root/testalign/aligntest.log
File sizes of 10 FASTQ input files referenced in '/usr/local/gotcloud-gotcloud.1.17.5/test/align/indexFile.txt' = 0.00 GB
Total temp space will be about 0.00 GB
Total space for BAM files will be about 0.00 GB
Be sure you have enough space to hold all this data
Created /root/testalign/aligntest/Makefiles/align_Sample1.Makefile
Created /root/testalign/aligntest/Makefiles/align_Sample2.Makefile
Created /root/testalign/aligntest/Makefiles/align_Sample3.Makefile
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Waiting while samples are processed...
Running make -f /root/testalign/aligntest/Makefiles/alignAll.Makefile > /root/testalign/aligntest/Makefiles/alignAll.Makefile.log 2> /root/testalign/aligntest/Makefiles/alignAll.Makefile.err...

Processing finished in 68 secs with no errors reported
Use of uninitialized value $ENV{"USER"} in concatenation (.) or string at /usr/local/gotcloud-gotcloud.1.17.5/scripts/runcluster.pl line 36.
Use of uninitialized value $ENV{"USER"} in concatenation (.) or string at /usr/local/gotcloud-gotcloud.1.17.5/scripts/runcluster.pl line 36.
Use of uninitialized value $ENV{"USER"} in concatenation (.) or string at /usr/local/gotcloud-gotcloud.1.17.5/scripts/runcluster.pl line 36.
Use of uninitialized value $ENV{"USER"} in concatenation (.) or string at /usr/local/gotcloud-gotcloud.1.17.5/scripts/runcluster.pl line 36.
Results from DIFF will be in /root/testalign/diff_logfiles_results.txt
Failed Makefile results validation. See mismatches in /root/testalign/diff_logfiles_results.txt
Comparison failed, test case FAILED.
CMD=/usr/local/gotcloud-gotcloud.1.17.5/scripts/diff_results_align.sh /root/testalign /usr/local/gotcloud-gotcloud.1.17.5/test/align/expected
```

So it seems as though the fastq files are not being recognized since it claims a total size of 0GB for them, even though the path to the files is correct. Please let me know if additional information is required, thanks.

title: Avoid the large scheduler overhead for short jobs
body:
**To use job arrays:**

I see two methods:
1. All instances of `runcluster.pl` have a mutex.  When `runcluster.pl` runs, it:
   1. writes a jobfile the directory `in_queue`
   2. acquires the mutex, using `flock`.
   3. checks how many other jobfiles have been written to that directory
   4. if some threshold has been met (eg, the oldest jobfile is > 30 seconds old, or there are > 50 jobfiles), it gathers up all the jobfiles, submits them as a job array, and removes them from that directory.
   5. if its jobfile doesn't get run in a minute, it submits it as a normal job.
2. All instances of `runcluster.pl` simply write out a jobfile.  A daemon (just a separate job running parallel to `make`) watches the output directory and deals with submitting job arrays.

Options for `runcluster.pl` to know the jobid to watch:
- The submitter writes a file mapping from script filename to jobid.  `runcluster.pl` first waits for this file to be created, and then waits for its job.
- `runcluster.pl` sets the jobname in the script, and then queries by job name.
  - On flux, `#PBS -N foo` will name a job.  I can't find a way to query a job by its `PBS_JOBNAME`, but I can view the name with `Job_Name = (.*)` in `qstat -f <jobid>`, so at least it would provide a nice sanity check.
  - On Slurm, we have `squeue --name=job_name`.
- `runcluster.pl` chooses the array id and puts it into the job's script's filename
  - On both slurm and flux, the array indexes can be specified with commas (like `1,14,42,66` rather than a simple range `14-18`).  Jobs' scripts' filenames could be of the format `<random_job_array_id>--<much_longer_random_string>`.  After writing a scriptfile, `runcluster.pl` could check whether a collision had occurred.  Then `runcluster.pl` would know the `PBS_ARRAYID`/`SLURM_ARRAY_TASK_ID` to query.
  - Flux appears to allow arbitrarily large array ids.  Slurm has a configuration variable `MaxArraySize`, which appears to actually limit the maximum array id.  `scontrol show config | grep MaxArraySize` is 20k on `nomosix`.  If something goes wrong, a worker job would just fail.
- Each worker writes its job id into `foo.jobid` right next to `foo.ok`

title: Use gcGetOptions to autogen documentation
body:
[gcGetOptions](https://github.com/statgen/gotcloud/blob/master/bin/gcGetOptions.pm) is already generating the `--help` output for a couple scripts.
1. It should be used for more scripts.
2. It should also generate mediawiki syntax for use on [the wiki](http://genome.sph.umich.edu/).

For reference, also see [this script](https://github.com/hyunminkang/apigenome/blob/6042b0fa25ce290d9a9dbc5f14119332233802b6/scripts/wGetOptions.pm).

title: Test on slurm and flux/torque
body:
1. `./gotcloud test` should support `--batchtype`.
2. Testing on a cluster should be better-documented. For example, [here](http://genome.sph.umich.edu/wiki/GotCloud:_Source_Releases).
3. I should manually use it.

title: Use a better `system` function
body:
( This issue should wait until we've merged the `runcluster.pl` changes on branch `peter-develop` into `master`.)

[System::Command](https://metacpan.org/pod/System::Command) will handle stderr and stdout.  Some examples of its use are [here](https://github.com/statgen/csg-mapper/search?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=system).

To use that, we need to:
1. Understand, fix, and clean our cpanfile mess.  Chris recommends moving to Carton, which builds on cpanm (and its cpanfile).  Then somehow link the two Makefiles.  Because of our reliance on `MAKECMDGOALS` in `src/Makefile`, submakes probably won't work.
2. Switch the `system` with `$qout` in `runcluster.pl`, which is one that would really benefit from capturing stdout and stderr.  Check what `qstat` and `squeue` output to stdout and stderr, and whether they're the same.  Otherwise, combine stderr and stdout.

@schelcj Is [Open3](http://perldoc.perl.org/IPC/Open3.html) worth using?  I like sticking to core perl when possible, and I don't see any immediate problems with Open3.

title: Track job resource usage on Flux
body:
- [x] Fetch job results from a dedicated email account.
- [ ] Use jobnames or timing to select jobs from the current `make`.
- [ ] Summarize `resources_used.cput`, `resources_used.mem`, and `resources_used.walltime`.
- [ ] Assert `Exit_status=0`.
- [ ] Classify jobs by task before summaries.  Use jobnames?

title: Update documentation on the wiki
body:
For reference, I've listed all gotcloud-related pages at http://genome.sph.umich.edu/wiki/Talk:GotCloud.
- The wiki contains some out-of-date information, which should be labeled more clearly.
- The [main page](http://genome.sph.umich.edu/wiki/GotCloud) should direct new users to installation instructions and then a tutorial more quickly.
  - For installation, we should recommend an approach.  Do we suggest using the `.deb` or downloading a release from github?  Is it `.deb` for admins, and github for non-admins?
    - Do we need to remove references to ftp://share.sph.umich.edu/gotcloud/?  Or bring it up to date?
  - Can we replace all testing information with `gotcloud test`?  It doesn't support `--batch`.  Does it need to support batches before we can recommend it exclusively?
- We don't have much information on `gotcloud indel`.

title: Create `gotcloud archive ...` to record what was done
body:
After we process data, we'd like for other people to be able to repeat our steps.

We need to record
- the commands that were run
- their arguments
- their versions

We could get this information:
- while running `align.pl,` `umake.pl`, and `pipeline.pl`.
- parsed out of the Makefile
  - Then just remove any lines starting with `for`, `mkdir`, etc.
  - How to figure out which targets we want, and in what order?  Maybe use `make --dry-run`?
- parsed out of the Makefile's output
  - Not all pipelines prefix important commands with `@`, so this won't work.

We could get the versions:
- hard-coded because the programs are included in the repository
- by checking them
  - eg, to get the version of `bwa`, run `bwa |& grep -Pio '(?<=version: ).+`
  - This handles commands that are overridden in `$PATH`.

Alternatively, we could just write simple instructions and scripts for doing all of this manually.

title: unify SAMTOOLS_SORT_EXE vs SAMTOOLS_EXE and BAMUTIL vs BAM_EXE
body:
I want to just set `SAMTOOLS_SORT_EXE = $(SAMTOOLS_EXE)`.  This could cause problems, but I certainly hope not.

`BAMUTIL` is used only by `umake.pl`, for `clipOverlap`. `BAM_EXE` is used only by `align.pl` and some places in config-derived pipelines.  I could set `BAMUTIL = $(BAM_EXE)`, but that might cause problems.

title: Specify dependencies more fully
body:
When installing on a fresh Ubuntu 16.10 server, I had to do `sudo apt-get install make cmake java-common default-jre libssl1.0.0 g++ libz-dev libncurses5-dev`.

`scripts/check_requirements.sh`:
- informed me about `make java-common default-jre`
- suggested `libssl0.9.8` which is no longer available (and `libssl1.0.0` passes the tests anyways)
- complained about missing `/usr/local/gotcloud/test/umake` even though I have `./gotcloud/test/umake`
- missed `cmake g++ libz-dev libncurses5-dev`

title: `cd src && make test` is failing on Ubuntu 16.10
body:
(`gcc 6.2.0`)

The error:

```
<...>
g++  -std=c++0x -ggdb -O0 -pipe -Wall  -I../libStatGen/include -I. -I../include/ -I../tabix  -D__ZLIB_AVAILABLE__ -D_FILE_OFFSET_BITS=64 -D__STDC_LIMIT_MACROS -DDATE="\"Fri Mar 24 01:25:27 EDT 2017\"" -DVERSION="\"0.1.1\"" -DUSER="\"cephas\""  -o bin/debug/glfFlex   obj/debug/GlfLikelihoods.o obj/debug/MathGold.o obj/debug/Main.o obj/debug/index.o    ../libStatGen/libStatGen_debug.a   -lm -lz
obj/debug/index.o: In function `ks_combsort_offt':
<...>/gotcloud/src/glfFlex/index.c:22: undefined reference to `__ks_insertsort_offt'
obj/debug/index.o: In function `ks_introsort_offt':
<...>/gotcloud/src/glfFlex/index.c:22: undefined reference to `__ks_insertsort_offt'
collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status
../libStatGen/Makefiles/Makefile.ext:43: recipe for target 'bin/debug/glfFlex' failed
<...>
```

`gotcloud/src/glfFlex/index.c` contains `KSORT_INIT(offt, pair64_t, pair64_lt)` which is defined  [here](https://github.com/statgen/gotcloud/blob/master/src/tabix/ksort.h#L70) in `gotcloud/src/tabix/ksort.h`.

When I remove the `inline` before `void __ks_insertsort_##name(type_t *s, type_t *t)`, the problem goes away.

Also, why does this error occur with `make test` and `make debug` but not `make`?  And what is `bin/debug/` for?

Comparison of final lines of `make test` and `make`:
```
# make test:
g++  -std=c++0x -ggdb -O0 -pipe -Wall  -I../libStatGen/include -I. -I../include/ -I../tabix  -D__ZLIB_AVAILABLE__ -D_FILE_OFFSET_BITS=64 -D__STDC_LIMIT_MACROS -DDATE="\"Fri Mar 24 02:20:05 EDT 2017\"" -DVERSION="\"0.1.1\"" -DUSER="\"cephas\""  -o bin/debug/glfFlex   obj/debug/GlfLikelihoods.o obj/debug/MathGold.o obj/debug/Main.o obj/debug/index.o    ../libStatGen/libStatGen_debug.a   -lm -lz
# make:
g++  -std=c++0x       -O4 -pipe -Wall  -I../libStatGen/include -I. -I../include/ -I../tabix  -D__ZLIB_AVAILABLE__ -D_FILE_OFFSET_BITS=64 -D__STDC_LIMIT_MACROS -DDATE="\"Fri Mar 24 02:20:07 EDT 2017\"" -DVERSION="\"0.1.1\"" -DUSER="\"cephas\""  -o bin/glfFlex     obj/GlfLikelihoods.o obj/MathGold.o obj/Main.o obj/index.o      ../libStatGen/libStatGen.a     -lm -lz
```

I get the same error if I use the `make` line but replace `obj/index.o` with `obj/debug/index.o`.

Comparison of lines producing `obj/debug/index.o` in `make test` and `obj/index.o` in  `make`:
```
# make test
gcc -ggdb -O0 -pipe -Wall  -I../libStatGen/include -I. -I../include/ -I../tabix  -D__ZLIB_AVAILABLE__ -D_FILE_OFFSET_BITS=64 -D__STDC_LIMIT_MACROS -DDATE="\"Fri Mar 24 02:25:50 EDT 2017\"" -DVERSION="\"0.1.1\"" -DUSER="\"cephas\"" -o obj/debug/index.o -c index.c
# make
gcc       -O4 -pipe -Wall  -I../libStatGen/include -I. -I../include/ -I../tabix  -D__ZLIB_AVAILABLE__ -D_FILE_OFFSET_BITS=64 -D__STDC_LIMIT_MACROS -DDATE="\"Fri Mar 24 02:25:34 EDT 2017\"" -DVERSION="\"0.1.1\"" -DUSER="\"cephas\"" -o obj/index.o -c index.c
```

If I use the `make` line but output to `obj/debug/index.o`, then the `make test` linking line works.

It looks like the problem is the `-O0` when compiling `obj/debug/index.o`.  If I change that, everything works.

title: `gotcloud test` fails on Ubuntu 16.10
body:
## `indel`
`HWE_LPVAL` and `HWE_LLR` often differ by up to 1% in:
```
test/indel/expected/indel/final/all.genotypes.vcf.gz
test/indel/expected/indel/final/merge/all.genotypes.20.bcf
```

## `beagle` & `thunder`
Fails because I'm missing the perl module `LWP/UserAgent.pm`.  `perl -MCPAN -e 'install Bundle::LWP'` can install it, fixing the issue.


`nan` was replaced by `NaN` in:
```
test/umake/expected/beagletest/beagle/chr20/chr20.filtered.PASS.beagled.vcf.gz
test/umake/expected/beagletest/beagle/chr20/split/bgl.1.chr20.PASS.1.vcf.gz
test/umake/expected/beagletest/thunder/chr20/ALL/split/chr20.filtered.PASS.beagled.ALL.split.1.vcf.gz
test/umake/expected/thundertest/thunder/chr20/ALL/thunder/chr20.filtered.PASS.beagled.ALL.thunder.1.vcf.gz
test/umake/expected/thundertest/thunder/chr20/ALL/thunder/chr20.filtered.PASS.beagled.ALL.thunder.vcf.gz
```

Lots of `.conf` files got re-ordered, but the ones I checked were all identical when sorted.

title: Fail encountered because of the verison of libStatGen in src/ is too old
body:
Hi There,

I encountered errors when compiling in scr/. 
I've fixed the error by replacing the libStatGen in src/ with the latest version (https://github.com/statgen/libStatGen.git). But it took me a while to find out the errors I met were because of the old version of libStatGen included in src/. 
You may want to replace src/libStatGen with the most recent version, in case other users met same problems.

Thanks!
